title: Analysis | The White House and the Secret Service: statements regarding a Senate panel’s findings
subtitle: Was the White House correctly characterizing the findings of a Senate panel report?
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
“I would point you to, again, the oversight that’s been done heretofore on this, which was released by a bipartisan panel chaired by Senators Claire McCaskill and Ron Johnson, who found that changes made to the draft IG report on Cartagena were ‘part of the ordinary process of editing that report.’”

One key element of the article concerned a separate probe by the Homeland Security Department’s Inspector General’s office, which had uncovered additional evidence from records and eyewitnesses who had accompanied the team member in Colombia. The article reported that David Neiland, the IG’s lead investigator, “later told Senate staffers that he felt pressure from his superiors in the office of Charles K. Edwards, who was then the acting inspector general, to withhold evidence — and that, in the heat of an election year, decisions were being made with political considerations in mind.”

The often dense report does not paint a pretty picture of Edwards’s tenure, saying “he failed to uphold the independence of the DHS Office of Inspector General (OIG) … jeopardized the independence of the OIG … directed reports to be altered or delayed to accommodate senior DHS officials … [and] also did not recuse himself from audits and inspections that had a conflict of interest related to his wife’s employment.” He resigned his post before the committee could hold a hearing on its findings.

In an interview with the Subcommittee, the lead investigator of the OIG’s USSS investigation stated he had been directed to delete derogatory information from the ROI. He stated that he received this direction from his supervisor but understood that the changes were being directed by Mr. Edwards. He also told the Subcommittee that he understood that these changes were being directed because the information was potentially damaging to the Administration. The agent also stated “Although I followed direction to remove certain information from the ROI, I made sure to include whatever was removed as a memorandum in the appendix.”

Now, with a section highlighted in bold, you can see what the White House did here. It took an assertion made by Edwards — “the changes that were directed were part of the ordinary process of editing the report” — and says that this was an actual finding of the report. But the panel itself did not reach such a specific conclusion. In fact, while the panel could not verify allegations concerning the Secret Service report, the overall report makes it clear that the panel does not believe Edwards is a very credible witness.

Still, in the case of the Secret Service allegations, Edwards was backed up by the assistant inspector general. The Senate panel also notes a separate investigation concerning an alleged threat to Nieland for having made allegations of political meddling; footnote 60 indicates there is a third supervisor interviewed as part of that probe who said Nieland was not asked to remove information for political purposes. But notes of that internal investigation also quote Nieland as saying he was not alleging a cover-up — but he later told Senate investigators that “the DHS OIG was sitting on information that could influence an election.”

In at least three instances, the Subcommittee report says it was unable to reach a conclusion with respect to an allegation because of a lack of evidence. Thus one could argue that “could not substantiate” is a stronger negative verdict than “could not conclude.” The Secret Service allegations against Edwards also did not warrant enough attention to be referenced in the executive summary of the report.

White House reporters are often too swamped to fully check out every assertion made by the White House’s press operation, and in this case officials seized on a phrase that is in the report. The report is rather complicated, and someone reading quickly might not catch the nuance that this was not actually a finding but merely a claim made by, among others, the very person whose credibility is questioned throughout the report.
